title: Replies to initial written questions raised by Finance Committee Members in examining the Estimates of Expenditure 2010-11
question_text: Regarding the work “to counter tax evasion, and minimise opportunities for tax avoidance”, the Government amended section 39E of the Inland Revenue Ordinance in 2006, saying that it was a means to combat tax avoidance schemes, and to recover tax deductions previously allowed for depreciation on machinery. As of to date, how many tax avoidance cases under section 39E have been detected and how much tax has been involved in total? For the past year, how many cases have the Inland Revenue Department taken actions on to recover tax deductions allowed for depreciation on machinery? How much tax was recovered successfully? In 2010-11, is it necessary to carry on such recovery actions and how much tax is expected to be recovered?
reply_text: Section 39E of the Inland Revenue Ordinance was enacted in 1986 and amended in 1992 to become the current version. The relevant provision stipulates that a Hong Kong company will be denied depreciation allowances if the machinery or plants owned by it are used wholly or principally outside Hong Kong by another company. In 2006, the Inland Revenue Department (IRD) updated the Departmental Interpretation and Practice Notes No.15 to provide detailed explanations and examples so as to facilitate taxpayers’ understanding of and compliance with the relevant provisions. That update did not change the scope of section 39E. The IRD has not kept records on the number of cases where adjustments were made in accordance with section 39E, nor on the amount of tax recovered. Section 39E will apply to any commercial arrangement falling within the specific scope of the provision. No estimate could be made on the amount of tax involved in this respect. Signature Name in block letters Mrs. CHU WONG Lai-fun, Teresa Post Title Ag. Commissioner of Inland Revenue Date 16 March 2010
